arch:property.oc:show_val: The pit contains large amounts of charcoal which were saved for carbon dating. There is also a yellowish residue (2.5y 6/4 light yellowish brown) that expanded into the trench and then retreated back under the baulk as we dug deeper. Samples of this soil were saved for testing. This pit rapidly narrowed and we did not follow the line accurately follow the line down. As a result this pit was dug about 30 cm too long on the side which cut L 4040. Thus some of the soil that is the same as L 4040 was dug in the pit locus. This is a problem only at the lower elevations. We may also have pushed through the bottom of the pit by about 5cm.
New locus boundaries set due to the marked change from a hard clay directly above to the new silty soil.

arch:note.arch:string: Contexts excavated in trenches were recorded using the "locus system." A locus is any discrete three-dimensional entity excavated in a trench. The key to the locus system is the recognition that a locus is any one thing. Differences in soil composition or texture are therefore as important as, for example, the difference between a pit and a wall. If two entities were distinct, they were considered separate loci and were therefore assigned separate locus numbers. It should also be noted that every context excavated in a trench was given a locus number and thus the trench itself is made up completely of excavated loci.

oc:metadata.dc:title: Kenan Tepe: Area F / Trench 4 / Locus 4034 (Locus)
